titleStmt.title: Minutes of Historical Advisory Committee Meeting, May 1992
HAC Meeting Minutes, 1992

head.hi: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HISTORICAL DIPLOMATIC DOCUMENTATION May 14-15, 1992

list.item: G. Alfred Kennedy, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Susan Povenmire
Joe Chaddic, Chief, Historical Documents Review Division
J. Kenneth McDonald, Central Intelligence Agency

div.p: Chairman Warren Kimball convened the meeting of the Advisory Committee on Historical Diplomatic Documentation at 9:15 a.m. The first item considered was adoption of the minutes of the last session. William Z. SIany, Executive Secretary of the Committee and Historian of the Department, asked if the minutes were adequate or perhaps more than adequate; he discussed options -- tape recording or stenography -- which were not feasible because of cost. The drafting, collating, and final editing of the minutes required at least 2 weeks of staff time. The Committee maintained that they preferred meeting minutes of the same complexity and depth and in the same format as previously.

Anna Nelson wished a clarification of the minutes covering John Fawcett’s presentation regarding mandatory review at the Presidential Libraries. David Herschler told her that the minutes had been corrected and clarified by both John Fawcett and Nancy Smith. Nelson, however, wanted the minutes corrected to reflect the fact that Fawcett had actually said that the average wait for mandatory review was 2 years. George Herring agreed.
With that clarification, the minutes were adopted unanimously.

Betty Glad asked about the public availability of the minutes. Slany noted that they are unclassified and probably should be distributed to historical societies. Ann Van Camp suggested that they be housed at the National Archives; Kimball suggested the Madison Reading Room at the Library of Congress. A notice could be sent to the societies that the minutes are available there. Page Miller noted that the records of the American Historical Association were at the Library of Congress. Kimball closed the discussion by indicating that he wants the minutes made available to researchers and historians.

Kimball next turned to adoption of the agenda and asked the Committee if anything should be added. Jane Picker asked if there would be time to discuss the access agreements and publication of the Digest of U.S. Practice in International Law. Slany indicated that he would discuss the access agreements in his report. Kimball remembered that the Committee was supposed to receive two written reports, one on the Digest and one on records management practices in the Department. Van Camp noted that the report was to cover only the broadest definition of records management: general Department problems and guidelines. Herschler said that Ken Rossman, the Department’s records manager, was overseas and had not yet provided such a report.

Nelson asked Kimball if he routinely submits a short report to Assistant Secretary of State Margaret Tutwiler. She would like to include on the agenda a small block of time to discuss what kind of action items the Committee would like its Chairman to report to Tutwiler. The Committee and Kimball agreed.

Kimball stressed that he would like to see on future agenda time reserved to hear from Foreign Relations compilers who are having or who foresee having problems with their volumes. Glenn W. LaFantasie, General Editor of the series, asked Kimball for a clarification. Kimball indicated that he was only interested in issues within the jurisdiction of the Committee: research, declassification, or other-agency access. He assured him that he did not want to set up a “back channel” for complaints or a bureaucratic appeal procedure to bypass the General Editor.

Emily Rosenberg asked about time to discuss issues relating to the Rosenberg/Van Camp subcommittee on declassification guidelines, which had not convened or prepared a report. Kimball said that these issues could be included in discussion of the Department’s report to Congress on opening records. The report of the Nelson/Picker subcommittee on access agreements, scheduled for later in the morning, could be switched to Friday morning.
The agenda was then adopted as amended.

Kimball called on Slany to make his report on the implementation of the Foreign Relations statute. He reported considerable progress on the two statutory requirements of the law: 1) written agreements to establish procedures for access to the foreign affairs records of other agencies, and 2) established procedures within the Department of State to meet the declassification deadlines. Under Secretary Rogers has expressed his concern and commitment that the Department meet the deadlines and is taking steps to ensure that. Slany noted that the Foreign Relations Production Schedule, which aims at achieving the 30-year line within 5 years, is the document that all in the Department have agreed to and are working from.*
* HDR has indicated that it does not agree to, but is working from, the PA/HO Foreign Relations Production Schedule.
Regarding the recommendations that the Committee made pursuant to its last meeting, Slany reported:

item.p:
1) the Department of State and the National Archives have concluded an agreement to provide a subvention to NARA for processing at the Johnson Library. On May 18, an additional archives technician will be detailed to the LBJ Library to assist in processing material for Department of State historians. Kimball noted in an
aside that the $14,000 came from the budget of the Advisory Committee and Nelson pointed out that the person who was detailed to the Johnson Library camefrom the declassification staff at the National Archives. Kimball ascertained, however, that although the person was detailed to Texas, the position would remain at NARA and would be filled.

2) The National Security Council and the Central Intelligence Agency have agreed to expedite the transfer of copies of their records in the Presidential Libraries to the Historical Office. They will no longer require prescreening of documents. All agreed that this was a major breakthrough in expediting compiling Foreign Relations volumes.

3) The CIA Historian has agreed that access to 1953 Iran and 1954 Guatemala documents is a high priority research project. The Director of Central Intelligence is, however, currently preoccupied with responding to legislative requests relating to the JFK assassination. The CIA acknowledges that the research will take place during the summer.

div.p: Kimball noted that this third point was important and must be followed up. He indicated it would head a list of Committee concerns. Kimball also expressed the pleasure of the Committee at the positive and quick response to its specific recommendations and requests.

Slany continued with his report on the status of the Foreign Relations series. The Office aimed at completing publication of the Eisenhower administration volumes, which had been compiled in the 1970s and 1980s, by the end of 1993. Office historians would be completing research on the Kennedy administration this year and would begin research on Johnson this summer. All agencies have now agreed to the Production Chart (aka the Perkins Chart) and are using it as a planning document. The Office has published 4 volumes so far this year and plans to publish a total of 13 this calendar year, and about 12 volumes next year.

Assistant Secretary Tutwiler has expressed her concern that the target dates in the Production Chart be adhered to. She has intervened with Assistant Secretary of State for Diplomatic Security Krys to ensure that the schedule is in place and that volumes will be returned from the National Security Council this spring. Kimball also noted that Tutwiler’s memorandum to all the Assistant Secretaries informing them of their bureaus obligations and responsibilities under the legislation has fulfilled a request made by the previous Advisory Committee.

Bradford Perkins pointed out time lags in declassification, especially for volumes on Asia. Slany replied that these volumes were compiled in the 1980s and suffered significant delays in declassification because there was neither a sense of urgency nor a coordinated effort to complete declassification. Perkins wanted to know if it indicated an unwillingness of any one bureau to declassify documents. Mabon clarified that declassification of these Asia volumes was held up in other agencies -- in the Department of Defense for the Korea volume, in the CIA for the Indonesia volume.

Nelson voiced her concern that documents that were not easily declassifiable would be omitted in order to meet deadlines and urged that the Department not sacrifice the quality of the series for timeliness. Kimball agreed that it was a major problem to balance scholarly and editorial integrity with the legislative deadlines. Rosenberg suggested that this issue could be part of the reports by Foreign Relations compilers on problems they are encountering. Compilers should know early in the process what kind of trade-offs will be necessary for their volumes.
Kimball noted that this problem of balancing will be getting bigger, not smaller, and that the Committee should consider defining a precedent for all volumes.

Arnold Taylor asked Slany about the use of graduate student interns in the Office of the Historian. Slany informed the Committee that the Office is scheduled to have four interns this summer and could use that many all year. The difficulty lies in recruitment and security clearance. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Kennedy noted that the universities would have to recruit suitable candidates during the first quarter of the academic year and the student would have to make a commitment so the Department of State could begin the personnel actions -- including security clearances -- by January 1.

Kimball next raised the issue of application of the 120-day legislative deadline for declassification review to volumes compiled before the statute. Does the legislation apply to volumes already in the declassification pipeline? Slany noted that he and Kennedy maintained an ongoing discussion on this very issue. He explained that even if the agencies dramatically speeded up their review, the Office still could handle only about 15 cleared volumes a year. Nevertheless he agreed that the remaining Eisenhower volumes still in the clearance pipeline should have been cleared by now.

Kimball wondered whether the Committee should become involved in expediting the declassification of these volumes. He stated that at the very least the Committee could register its serious concern over the declassification delay. He added
that he anticipated that the other agencies responsible for clearing portions of Foreign Relations volumes would not be anxious to go before Congress to explain why they were not in compliance with the legislation.

Slany indicated that HO has worked with Joe Chaddic and the Department’s declassification staff to negotiate with other agencies to reach an agreement that the legislation applies to these volumes as well as to those entering the declassification process since enactment of the legislation. Both Kennedy and Slany preferred that the Committee refrain from taking action on this subject and allow the Department to work out a solution to this serious problem.

Kennedy informed the Committee that both Rogers and Tutwiler are serious about implementing the legislation; neither wants to report to Congress that the Department of State has not complied. Rogers has said that he will do all that he can within his scope of responsibility and he is currently working on a plan, which will be thoroughly vetted within the Department, to meet the legislative requirements. Kennedy vowed that the Bureau of Public Affairs will do all it can to make sure that the volumes will be complete and accurate and will meet all scholarly standards. He has instituted an “early warning system” to detect problems at an early stage so they can be resolved. If the Committee can help in any way, he will certainly ask.

Turning to the planning for the Johnson administration volumes, Slany reminded the Committee that he had often in the past asked for their advice. The Department plans to meet the requirements of the statute to publish a complete and accurate record but must also operate within the limitations and constraints of the real world:

item.p: the amount of documents that can be accessed and gathered from the Johnson Library (without disabling the Library);
the limited resources of other agencies in both facilitating access and declassifying documents;
the limited resources of the Historical Office.

div.p:
The Bureau of Public Affairs has consistently provided enough money for publication of the Foreign Relations volumes; it has in fact become the largest item in PA’s budget. But all of the Federal government is trying to curb spending and reduce the deficit. Secretary of State Baker in April requested all bureaus to make budget cuts in order to provide the resources for establishing new Embassies in the former Soviet republics. Tutwiler has assured him that HO’s budget will not be reduced,
but also charged him with completing all those volumes for which funds have been earmarked. Nor were there limits on travel and research for Department historians. Slany stated his belief that additional staff was not the solution. Processing and handling procedures and requirements at the Presidential Libraries and other agencies limit the number of State Department researchers that can be accommodated.

He again asked for the Committee’s advice and support in the selectivity the Office must exercise in compiling the Johnson administration volumes given the number of agencies and the volume of records. The proposed volumes would have to be considered case-by-case. Kimball agreed that this is a fundamental issue before the Committee and would be discussed throughout the rest of the 2-day sessions.

Van Camp indicated that she would like to defer her report on declassification guidelines until the next meeting in view of the fact that the Department is making changes to the guidelines. Rosenberg said she would like to discuss these changes during this meeting.

On the issues of the State Department Report to Congress on Opening Records at 30 Years, Slany deferred to Chaddic, who noted that the report was included in the packet circulated to the Committee. He stated that he thought the report spoke for itself, and that he as drafting officer had tried to provide what was required. He only wished that he could have brought the report to the Committee’s attention sooner, but the bureaucratic procedures of preparing and transmitting the document to Congress had taken longer than anticipated. He said that next time his office would begin the process sooner. Chaddic then invited the Committee’s comments on the report.

Nelson requested verification that the completed systematic declassification review of the 1955-1959 records only covers central decimal files and not the Department’s lot files. The report was also unclear on whether the legislation covers records from the 1930s and 1940s at NARA that are still unreviewed. Page Miller informed the Committee that NARA has these records, including declassification guidelines, but does not have the resources to review them under systematic review and only reviews these documents when they are requested by a researcher. Kimball pointed out that the system of reviewing older files only when they were specifically requested was probably the best approach since he personally was not in favor of diverting resources away from declassification of files currently in the 30 year window.

Chaddic indicated that State and NARA have agreed that the lot and decimal files for the 1960-1963 record block will be reviewed together. Nelson welcomed this development but expressed doubt that the declassifiers would be able to handle this much larger volume of records and meet their deadlines.
She also insisted that the minutes should be clear that only the review of the central files had been completed through 1959. Rosenberg added that the Committee faced a potential public relations problem with its academic constituencies, which tended to believe that under the new legislation everything would be open after 30 years. She advised that the Committee inform the historical associations that this in fact would not be the case. Nelson pointed out the necessity for NARA to request additional resources to implement the legislation.

In connection with the general discussion about the incomplete declassification of older records, Perkins mentioned his difficulty in seeing INR files when he had last been at the National Archives. Slany stated that in the case of INR as well as other files a related problem was that often files were segregated, held separately and not turned over to NARA, or were destroyed in the Department during the screening process. He urged the Committee to make recommendations about identifying and preserving bodies of files and suggested that the Committee consider recommending preparation of a records management report on INR files that would emphasize preservation.

Before the break, Kimball introduced some general thoughts that he hoped Committee members would consider before the meeting was reconvened. He personally expressed annoyance that President Bush’s signing statement qualifying the legislation was repeated frequently throughout the report to Congress. He also presented for the Committee’s consideration the desirability of HDR instituting a flow chart similar to the one created by HO identifying target dates for the aggregate declassification of files sent to the National Archives. Finally, he directed the Committee’s attention to the questionable legality of the designation in the Department’s report to Congress of the youngest records in each record block as the ones determining the age of all the documents in the file rather than the oldest records.
At approximately 10:45 a.m., the Committee recessed for a break.
Kimball asked if the Department’s report on opening 30-year-old records had gone to Congress, and was assured by Slany that it had.

Noting the presence of Ken McDonald, Chief of the CIA History Staff, Kimball asked members of the subcommittee on interagency agreements if they wished to pursue any issues with
McDonald. Nelson suggested that the subcommittee report later on all concerns at a general level, and privately direct any specific questions about the CIA agreement to McDonald. Perkins asked McDonald about the CIA review of documents on Iran and Guatemala. McDonald explained that in testimony this week DCI Gates has promised Congress that CIA will give first priority to declassification review of some 330,000 pages of Kennedy assassination records. Since the new group that is reviewing historical records is not yet fully staffed, and review of the Kennedy papers could take from six to 18 months, it will be some time before the new group can take on such projects as Iran and Guatemala.

Kimball asked if the CIA could provide an outline of its work plan. McDonald indicated that while he was not in a position to do that now, he would hope that reviewers could be assigned to undertake projects of special interest to the Department of State once the new Historical Review Group has the Kennedy papers well in hand. The CIA History Staff’s work in support of State historians compiling Foreign Relations volumes will, of course, move forward now that CIA and State have concluded their Memorandum of Understanding on procedures.

Referring to his final comments before the break, Kimball noted that he was troubled by frequent references in the Department’s report to Congress on opening 30-year-old records and the attached fiscal report to the President’s signing statement at the time of enactment of the legislation. He was also troubled by the phrases “traditional” procedures and “spirit” of the mandate, which he said could be interpreted as a means of non-compliance with the legislation.

Chaddic responded that these phrases were not meant to avoid the law and he did not think the President’s signing statement would have much impact on the declassification process. The phrases in question were meant to make the case for additional funding that would better enable DS to comply with the legislation.
Kimball and Glad suggested that the funding concerns, described in part by Chaddic, be articulated to Congress.

Kimball reiterated his view that the law indicates that the oldest document determines when a block reaches 30 years, not the most recent. He indicated that the Department’s interpretation was not in compliance with the law, but asserted that the Committee understands the “realities” with regard to meeting the legislative deadlines. Although it may take time to reach, the Department should establish a 30-year line for the oldest records in the block as its goal. He then urged HDR to provide rough target dates for its declassification program.
Kimball asked Chaddic if he was comfortable with the Committee’s advice.
Chaddic welcomed the Committee’s advice. He then described his staff’s efforts to work out international agreements and cooperation on declassification.
Herring inquired about the likelihood of DS accelerating declassification in support of the legislation.
Chaddic assured the Committee of HDR’s good intentions in this regard, and described several HDR initiatives to accomplish this acceleration.

Herring stated that declassification guidelines were outdated because of the changed international climate since they were written (i.e., cold war tensions). He wondered if a new approach should be sought.

Rosenberg suggested Herring’s inquiry would best be taken up by her subcommittee, which would be looking into the Department’s declassification guidelines and would have a report for the next meeting.
Perkins asked that declassification guidelines be made available to the Committee during its review of Foreign Relations volumes. The Committee and Chaddic supported this request.
Kimball and Page Miller asked Chaddic if the $3 million said to be devoted to 20 new declassifier positions for review of the 1960-1963 records was firm. Chaddic indicated that it was.
The Committee then turned to consideration of the plan for the Foreign Relations volumes covering the Johnson administration.

LaFantasie provided an overview of the plan for the LBJ volumes. The scope and conception of the Johnson volumes, he said, would have to be adjusted to fit the mandate of the law by taking several exigencies into account. He pointed out that the conception of the LBJ volumes that he was presenting to the Committee had been developed as a result of a careful and intricate assessment of the realities that we must face -- the practical limitations that control how much we can do and how much we cannot, including the number of pages, contents, and research and production schedules. The Foreign Relations series, he said, was now facing serious constraints and realities that cannot be ignored, such as time factors, personnel numbers, the dynamics of the declassification process, and funding limitations. The conception of the LBJ subseries is, for all intents and purposes, being dictated by the practical realities we are facing.

Each of these practical aspects has been carefully weighed in designing the plan for the LBJ volumes, he said. Actually, he pointed out, several of these ideas had been presented earlier to the former Advisory Committee in the early 1980s, 1984, and 1988. The scope of the LBJ subseries is not arbitrary. Instead the conception comes from constraints we are facing, the standards of content and deadlines set by the Foreign Relations statute, and the conventional methods of selectivity and annotation that have been widely adopted in the field of documentary editing.

According to present plans, the LBJ subseries will consist of anywhere from 33 to 36 volumes. He explained that consultation with division chiefs and compilers since the last Advisory Committee meeting resulted in a proposed increase of 3 volumes over the number originally put forth in previous plans. Each volume, he said, would consist of approximately 800 pages and would cover the five-year period from 1964 to 1968 (except for the Vietnam volumes and some “crisis” volumes). He acknowledged that the explosion of documentation would make the selection of documents for each volume more difficult, creating a formidable intellectual challenge that the compilers would have to confront and deal with, but he pointed out that it should be possible to create volumes that were highly selective but that still told the major stories needing to be covered and could point the user to additional sources not printed.

He referred to the tables of contents that had been submitted earlier to members of the committee and pointed out that these contents were for 36 volumes rather than 33. He said that several factors would have to be considered before the number of volumes was increased, including the availability of staff within divisions to complete the extra volumes, the availability of funding to pay for the production costs, the means by which the available staff would accomplish work on the extra volumes while still meeting the mandated deadlines of the Foreign Relations statute, and the potential impact additional volumes would have on the declassification process in State and in the other agencies.

LaFantasie said that the reduction of the volumes to approximately 800 pages would be accomplished by rigorous selection of materials during the research and compiling phases but also by a reduction of annotation. He pointed out that one common practice among modern documentary editions is called “clustering,” whereby one document is selected for publication as representative of similar documents and then annotation is appended to the printed document to reveal the location and nature of the similar documents that could not be included for publication. He also said that some detail in footnotes could be eliminated.

He spoke about the elimination of microfiche supplements as part of the new approach to the LBJ subseries and said that the elimination was necessary to meet the legislative timeframe with the limitations of existing resources for compiling, declassifying, and publishing the volumes. In some respects, he said, each fiche supplement equals a single volume of Foreign Relations, insofar as each fiche requires time and effort to research, arrange, compile, declassify, and produce.
Following LaFantasie’s summary presentation, the Committee recessed for lunch at 12:05.

The Committee reconvened at 1:30 p.m. Discussion centered on a subcommittee review of Foreign Relations, 1955-1957, vol. XXIII, Part 2, Korea. Chaddic provided each member of the Committee with copies of the Department declassification guidelines for Korea 1955-1957 and Japan 1958-1960 (scheduled to be discussed Friday morning). Kimball noted that Perkins, the other member of this subcommittee, could not come early to review the volume, so Kimball did it the previous day. He indicated that there were inconsistencies in the clearance process which may have occurred because a clearance folder was lost and not found in the course of submitting, reviewing, and resubmitting the documents.

quote.p: [Pages 13-17 consist of a classified discussion of Foreign Relations, 1955-1957, Vol. XXIII, Part 2, Korea. Copies of the classified minutes are available in PA/HO.]

div.p: The Committee then returned to a discussion of the draft tables of contents to the volumes on the Johnson administration. Glad asked to what degree the Vietnam volumes duplicated the Pentagon Papers, if they were useful, and what will be new in the Foreign Relations volumes. Mabon responded that the Pentagon Papers ceased in mid-1967, and did not contain much 1967 material. Herring agreed that there was not much for 1967 in certain areas, and it was mostly a Defense Department study that did not take into account other agency documentation, including State documents. Nelson added that the NSC did not cooperate in the Pentagon project. Ted Keefer said that if the document was crucial, it was printed in Foreign Relations, and the others were only cited. LaFantasie remarked that there is much more to the Vietnam volumes than the Pentagon Papers.

Perkins wondered whether there was perhaps too much coverage of Vietnam. He thought there was a lot of repetition in the 1964 volume, for example, and cited the many Khanh-Lodge memcons. Perhaps the historians had been “seduced” into believing that Vietnam was so important. LaFantasie responded that it was not seduction, he hoped, but the result of earlier decisions to continue the major story lines. Vietnam was not a model for the rest of the 1964-1968 volumes. Specimen documents were printed, and related ones were cited in annotation. Keefer rejoined, “I disagree 100 percent” with Perkins’ point on the Lodge-Khanh memcons, and he explained that there were many more that were not printed. Charles Sampson added that the Vietnam volumes were a model for research planning of the other 1964-1968 because many other repositories were first searched for the Vietnam volumes. LaFantasie agreed and thought that the prefaces were a stepping off point (if not a model) for the others. He circulated the preface to the 1964 volume. Nelson said that she does not have the Vietnam volumes; the new members have only received the most recent ones. Slany said that the minutes should indicate that the other volumes should be sent to the new members.

Glad commended the sources consulted for the Vietnam volumes. Nelson and Herring agreed that a lot of documentary sources are no longer in State Department files. LaFantasie intimated that he was conceiving of an essay on sources for future volumes, and he circulated a review of the 1958-1960 Cuba volume in the Pacific Historical Review on the universe of sources, among other things. Rosenberg raised the question of where to stop on including secondary sources in prefaces. LaFantasie said that the emphasis of essays on sources would focus only on primary sources. Herring and Nelson disagreed with the need for historiographical essays, which were very difficult to write. LaFantasie said the essay would not just list the sources but describe them substantively.

Kimball asked what researchers needed from the prefaces to assist their work. Nelson asserted that the documentary record had exploded since World War II, and the HO historians cannot see all the records. David Patterson confirmed that he recently was able to look at only 20 out of about 300 boxes in one AID lot file for the Kennedy years. LaFantasie replied that the essay would be limited to what the compilers know. Glad said any such essays should not be final authoritative statements but representative of the compilers’ best judgments.
Glad and Rosenberg also asked questions and made suggestions for coverage of other issues, particularly military assistance policy and information policy.
The Committee recessed for a break at 3:30.

The Committee reconvened at 3:45. Discussion of the Johnson volumes turned to the draft table of contents which had been distributed to the Committee. Perkins asked Slany to describe the process of preparing it. He replied that he and the former Editor in Chief had prepared the first draft in consultation with the compilers in 1989 and shown it to the Committee at that time. Mabon had coordinated a second draft at the end of 1990 which also had input from the entire compiling staff. The present draft had been prepared in the past two months under LaFantasie’s leadership. LaFantasie explained that the process was interactive between the General Editor, the Division Chiefs, and the compilers. The present draft was by no means cast in concrete and the Office wanted the Committee’s suggestions.

Perkins asked if the Committee should suggest changes of emphasis. Slany pointed out that the February 1991 Action Plan envisaged consultation with experts by way of further refining the Johnson plan.

Rosenberg believed the present draft neglected Latin America because it had been alloted only three volumes out of up to 36. In addition, there were debatable allocations within those three volumes, such as the entire volume devoted to the Dominican Republic and almost a full volume on Cuba. There were not enough pages for Brazil, Panama, and Nicaragua, and there was no allocation for Mexico. In general -- and this appeared to be the case with the entire Johnson sub-series as well -- there was too great an emphasis on military action and crises and not enough on economics. Perkins said that it was preposterous to devote so much time to the Dominican crisis, which was essentially a six-weeks’ wonder.

Mabon responded that page allocations for individual compilations in the Western Hemisphere volume were extremely flexible and to a great extent the final result would reflect the quality of the documentation as well as the significance of the events covered. A more recent draft of this volume did have a page allocation for Mexico. If many of the bilaterals were expanded, it might be possible to take pages away from Cuba and group some of Central America with it. He hesitated to recommend shortening the Dominican coverage at this time because of the high-level involvement of U.S. officials, the evidence this crisis gave of Johnson’s operating style, and the long-term effect of the crisis on the Alliance for Progress and the inter-American system. Although regional economic coverage perhaps needed to be strengthened, the Foreign Relations series was to some extent based on the preoccupations of the highest officials at the time events occurred, and it documented the foreign and national security policy process as well as relations with other nations.

Taylor wondered if narcotics smuggling should get more attention. Keefer gave his opinion that narcotics smuggling was not yet an acute problem in this time period and that extended coverage of it might raise the problem of “reading history backwards” by actively seeking out and describing the antecedents of issues that only later became important.

Herring said that the U.S. force structure was perhaps the biggest national security issue during 1967-68 and he did not see it emphasized in the draft. Kimball asked if there should be a whole volume on foreign policy organization. Nelson responded emphatically in the affirmative, and Slany pointed out that the Kennedy and Johnson periods had seen the disestablishment of the Department of State as the chief foreign policy arm of the United States Government and that the organizational as well as the operational aspects of the transition were of the most profound importance. Mabon added that the period saw the establishment of the modern NSC, with its powerful Adviser and staff of area and functional experts. Slany pointed out the establishment of or enhanced role of such other agencies as the USIA, the Peace Corps, and ACDA. Further discussion revealed a consensus that while the organizational volume was important, finding worthy documentation for it would be difficult. Harriet Schwar asserted that there would be considerable documentation in individual stories reflecting organizational changes.

Kimball indicated that he was not suggesting that the volume on organizational structure be dropped, but if more pages were needed to cover other more important topics, he wondered where the space would come from.

Discussion moved back to questions of editorial technique. Nelson said she hoped that page cuts would not be accompanied by a cut in annotation which summarized important related documents and furnished other useful information. LaFantasie said that annotation was important and would not be jettisoned, but simply be brought back into control. Footnotes describing social occasions, for example, might be dropped. Perkins felt that as the number of documents decreased, the series owed the reader more in the way of annotation. LaFantasie agreed, but pointed out that footnote inflation needed to be kept in check. As a documentary editor, he was committed to publishing the texts of documents. The compiler’s job would admittedly be more difficult than ever.

Kimball indicated that he was uncomfortable with abstract discussion about major changes planned for the series. The Committee was being asked to comment on new approaches and ideas, but after today’s discussion he was not certain what these approaches were. He suggested that the Office designate one of the Johnson volumes early in the compiling process so that the Committee could be involved in the “nitty-gritty” of selection and annotation. Slany pointed out that it would be at least a half-year before a Johnson volume reached this stage, but stated it might be possible for the Committee to look at a Kennedy volume. He asked if the Committee wished to bring in experts to look at tables of contents. Herring was not convinced either of these proposals was needed. At least in his area, he thought the compilers had in the past resolved problems of selection and annotation quite well. Nelson said that if the Committee was to have any input into the compiling process, it should get involved now. Kimball agreed that the Committee should consider setting up a subcommittee to examine proposed editorial methodology for the Johnson volumes.

There was further discussion about significant issues that should be documented in the Johnson years. Picker noted that with the advent of communications satellites there should be coverage of general telecommunications policy. Rosenberg noted the importance of covering information policy, foreign economic policy, and military and economic assistance programs. Mabon pointed out that these had been covered in many volumes, including those on Southeast Asia. Kimball wondered where HO would find documents on information policy, since USIA stated it did not have many documents. Slany said the Office would find out.

Taylor asked if there would be documents on the international impact of the civil rights movement. Nina Noring indicated that occasional documentation on Africa touched on the racial situation in the United States, but that with tight page constraints HO’s ability to cover such incidents as discrimination faced by African diplomats in the United States
was limited and impinged on the compiler’s ability to cover such subjects as Apartheid. Taylor said that he was not referring exclusively to coverage of Africa and hoped that in regard to overall U.S. foreign policy, Foreign Relations would print as much as possible, within page constraints, on civil rights issues.

Nelson wanted to know why the volumes were being cut back since there was even more covert action in the 1960s than in the 1950s. Van Camp felt that the Committee must come to grips with the central issue of not being able to publish more and more documents. Until it was possible to publish electronically, there would have to be constraints.

There was a brief discussion about the potential use of CD ROM. After being informed that CD ROM was not yet a possibility for anything but replication of already-printed volumes, Nelson suggested retention of microfiche. LaFantasie cautioned that the problem with microfiche was work hours, both in PA/HO and in HDR. If the Committee wanted microfiche, it was back to the drawing board on everything. Nelson thought that in some ways the purpose of the legislation would be defeated by a reduction in size, but LaFantasie pointed out that the series was highly selective anyway. There was also no valid information as yet on utilization, and therefore cost-effectiveness, of microfiche.
Kimball asked the Committee to consider the idea of a subcommittee working with the Office on a Kennedy administration volume that would exemplify the compression envisaged for the Johnson years.
The Committee adjourned at 5:00 p.m.

div.p: The Subcommittee on Foreign Relations, 1958-1960, Vol. XVII, Japan (Glad, Herring, and Taylor) presented its report. Copies of a classified synopsis of declassification issues, a precis of withheld documents, and a draft memorandum to Under Secretary for Political Affairs Arnold Kanter (P) were given to committee members to read.

quote.p: [Pages 24-28 consist of a classified discussion of Foreign Relations, 1958-1960, Vol. XVII, Japan. Copies of the classified minutes are available in PA/HO.]

div.p: The Committee recessed at 10:45 for a coffee break.
[Following the break, the Committee convened in executive session to discuss its recommendations on Foreign Relations, 1958-1960, Vol. XVII, Japan. The Committee recessed for luncheon at 12:05.]

During the working luncheon, the Committee heard a report from Anna Nelson representing the subcommittee on interagency agreements on access. The other member of the subcommittee, Jane Picker, had not received her package because she had been away. She had an opportunity to briefly examine the package during the course of the Committee meeting and indicated that Nelson’s report represented the subcommittee’s views.

Nelson commented on several of the agreements or memoranda on access received from the various agencies. In particular, she expressed concern with the separate letter of agreement provided by the Department of Defense. The letter represented procedures for OSD records but was unclear whether the procedures also included the other military agencies. The DOD procedures outlined in the December 4 memorandum seemed cumbersome. There was also concern that access by the Advisory Committee was not fully dealt with in accord with the legislation, and that the OSD historian was not involved in this arrangement, as stipulated in the legislation. The Committee urged the Historian to go back to DOD and seek access agreements with all military agencies in accordance with the legislation. Slany indicated that it would be helpful to have something in writing from the Committee with which to approach DOD, and Kimball asked Nelson to draft the Committee’s recommendation.

Nelson mentioned that the NSA letter was in effect a refusal to sign an agreement, although it did assign a liaison to cooperate in the NSA participation in the Foreign Relations series. Kimball suggested that the Department Historian approach NSA with a request on the Committee’s behalf to spell out the access procedures in an agreement. At Slany’s request, Kimball agreed that the Committee would put this recommendation in writing.

With regard to the Memorandum of Understanding with the CIA, Nelson expressed concern with use of the word “timely” in CIA’s reference to providing security clearances and need to know for access by Department Historians and members of the Advisory Committee. The Committee recommended a follow-up by HO and/or the Committee with Ken McDonald on this point.

Nelson also raised minor concerns over the language of one or two items in the NARA and NSC agreements. Overall, however, she indicated satisfaction with the agreements that had been obtained, and asserted cautious optimism over their implementation. The Committee concurred in these views.
[The Committee convened in executive session from 1:15 until 1:40 to continue it deliberations over the Japan compilation.]

Following the executive session, the Committee reconvened at 1:40. Discussion continued on the plan for the Johnson volumes. Kimball proposed establishing a subcommittee to go over the tables of contents for the volumes and proposed changes in editorial methodology with LaFantasie.

Rosenberg expressed concern that the Committee would be micromanaging the General Editor’s efforts to improve and modernize Foreign Relations. She favored the typical modes of Committee review for evaluating the adequacy of the volumes.

Nelson said she was interested in looking at LaFantasie’s proposed changes and would serve on the subcommittee. Arnold Taylor also agreed to serve on this subcommittee, which was tasked with looking at how LaFantasie’s ideas would be carried out practically in a newly compiled Kennedy volume. This subcommittee will plan to meet with LaFantasie in June. The Committee decided to defer consideration of the 800 page/36 volume Johnson sub-series issue until it heard the results of the Nelson-Taylor subcommittee.

In response to Kimball’s query about upcoming problem volumes in the declassification pipeline, David Herschler said that the committee may want to review the declassification decisions on two compilations that were currently under appeal: Indonesia (1958-1960 and 1961-1963) and National Security Policy (1958-1960). HO had just been informed that the CIA may have a favorable response on the Indonesia issue (first brought to the Committee’s attention a year ago), but the Committee may want to appoint a subcommittee to review National Security Policy, pending results of the current appeal with CIA and an anticipated appeal to DOD.. Brad Perkins agreed to serve on the subcommittee with Jane Picker.

As an aside, Kimball brought up the fact that State Department lawyers have determined that the “terms” of current members of the Committee under the law begin as of September 1, 1992 and expire August 31, 1993.

Picker spoke about the concern of the American Society of International Law in the Department’s proposal to cancel publication of the Law Digest and how the Foreign Relations series could cover some of this material. The Committee agreed to place this item on the agenda for the next meeting.
The Committee built the following tentative agenda for its next meeting:

item.p: (1) Johnson volume planning and editorial policy: subcommittee report
(2) State declassification procedures and guidelines: subcommittee report
(3) National Security Policy declassification: subcommittee report
(4) Follow-up on implementation of the legislation
(5) Records management in the Department
(6) Treaty Series
(7) Department cancellation of the Law Digest

div.p: Kimball tried to get agreement on dates for the next meeting of the Committee, but was unable to do so. Slany will canvass Committee members soon about possible dates in July, September, and October.

Perkins asked if there was anything the Committee could do about the withholding from publication in Foreign Relations of documents that were already in the public domain. Kimball said he knew of two documents that were in the National Archives and yet were not cleared for publication in Foreign Relations. Slany added that some day the Department may not publish documents but have them cleared and made available for research.
The Committee adjourned at 2:15.

head.hi: ADVISORY COMMITTEE CONCERNS RESULTING FROM MEETING ON MAY 14-15, 1992

div.p: [As Reported by the Committee Chairman]

item.p: 1. CIA response regarding access to 1954 Guatemala records and 1953 Iran records.
2. Delays in declassification of Foreign Relations volumes, particularly at other agencies for volumes that were in the declassification process prior to enactment of P.L. 102-138.
3. The requirement of accelerating preparation and publication of Foreign Relations to meet the legislative deadlines may result in the exclusion of important documents.

4. The need for “older” Department records at the National Archives to be reviewed and declassified, and public dissemination of information that such files currently not reviewed and declassified will be reviewed upon researcher request.
5. A request for a Department report on general records management in the Department and a separate report (or a focus in the general report) on the disposition of INR records.
6. The Department should give Congress early notice of requirement for more resources to meet the legislative mandate for declassification and opening of Department records at 30 years.

7. Despite the problem of file breaks and within acceptable archival practice, the principal of declassification of Department records at 30 years (i.e., the oldest record in a record block) should be the ultimate goal.
8. Bureaucratic confusion and inconsistency in the declassification process.
9. The need for consistency in the application of declassification standards in the Foreign Relations clearance process.
10. The assumption that the CIA will now acknowledge that covert actions were planned and occurred.
